awd_titl_txt: Low-Dimensional Topology, Floer Homology, and Categorification
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates a variety of questions in low-dimensional topology, the study of the global shapes of 3- and 4-dimensional spaces and of knots and surfaces contained within them. This subject lies at the crossroads of many disparate areas of mathematics, and it has a wide variety of applications ranging from cosmology (the shape of the universe) to biochemistry (the knotting of DNA molecules) to mathematical physics. Surprisingly, many problems in low dimensions are usually more difficult than their analogues in higher dimensions and require the use of invariants that go beyond traditional algebraic topology. The PI's particular area of expertise is in Heegaard Floer homology, a collection of invariants for 3- and 4-dimensional manifolds, which has been one of the most fruitful areas of research in low-dimensional topology since the early 2000s. These tools bring together several different fields of mathematics, including representation theory, differential geometry, and analysis, and the PI hopes to elucidate the connections between these different areas and expand the discourse among researchers in these fields.

The specific goals of the project are (1) to make progress on a variety of concrete problems in 4-manifold topology, including knot concordance, exotic smooth structures, and embeddings of non-orientable surfaces; (2) to understand the relationship between the Heegaard Floer homology of a 3-manifold and topological properties such as the existence of incompressible surfaces, taut foliations, and left-orderings on the fundamental group; (3) to establish relationships between the knot invariants arising from gauge theory and symplectic geometry and those coming from representation theory and quantum algebra.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: My research concerns a variety of problems in low-dimensional topology, involving 3- and 4-dimensional manifolds and the interactions between them. I work primarily with tools coming from Heegaard Floer homology and Khovanov homology, two important packages of invariants developed in the early 2000s. During the period of this grant, I have used these tools to prove many innovative results about a variety of questions in low-dimensional topology.

Intellectual Merit: During the period of the grant, I completed seven research papers, all of which have now been published, accepted, or accepted with revisions in competitive research journals. Most of these are related to questions regarding smoothly embedded surfaces in 4-dimensional manifolds. One such question concerns knot concordance, which is essentially the classification of which knots in 3-dimensional space bound smoothly embedded disks in 4 dimensions. These questions are deeply tied to the fundamental strangeness of 4-dimensional topology, as compared with higher dimensions. I will just highlight a few of my main contributions:

  1. Just before the start of the grant period, I showed that the so-called piecewise-linear concordance group is nontrivial, illustrating an unusual phenomenon of certain 4-dimensional spaces and answering a question from the 1970s. Shortly thereafter, in joint work with Jennifer Hom (Georgia Institute of Technology) and Tye Lidman (North Carolina State University) that appeared in 2018, we built drastically on this result, showing that this group is "large": it is infinitely generated and contains elements of infinite order. After an extensive review process, this paper was recently accepted by the prestigious Duke Mathematical Journal.
  2. On a related topic, Lidman and I also produced the first known example of a 4-manifold which is homotopy equivalent to the 2-dimensional sphere --- i.e., its overall algebraic topology is the same as that of the sphere --- but does not contain a "spine," a piecewise-linear embedded sphere representing the homotopy equivalence. The existence of such a manifold was another long-standing open problem.
  3. In 2019-20, I was part of a large flurry of activity concerning ribbon concordance, an asymmetric relation on knots in 3-space. In a short joint paper with Ian Zemke (which built on a previous paper of his from a few weeks prior), we showed that two knots that are mutually ribbon concordant are indistinguishable by Khovanov homology. This provided evidence in support of a larger conjecture (from the early 1980s) that two knots that are mutually ribbon concordant must in fact be equivalent, which was subsequently proven in 2022 by Ian Agol. My work with Zemke then formed the background for a paper that I wrote together with an undergraduate student, Onkar Gujral, about the behavior of the Khovanov homology invariants for certain types of surfaces in 4 dimensions, which recently appeared in Journal of Topology.


Broader Impacts: During the period of the grant, I have successfully integrated my research activities with my passion for education and mathematical outreach. Some of these activities include:

  1. During the course of the grant, I supervised my first Ph.D. student, Seppo Niemi-Colvin, who received some research support from the grant. After writing a superb thesis, he recently graduated from Duke and is heading to a postdoctoral fellowship at Indiana University.
  2. In 2019-20 and 2020-21, I supervised research projects for two undergraduates at Duke. The first of those projects, with Onkar Gujral, was a tremendously fruitful collaboration and led to a paper in a prestigious journal, as discussed above; Gujral has gone on to graduate study at MIT. I recently started supervising a third such student project.
  3. During the 2019-20 school year, I met weekly with a group of students from the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics, a public magnet high school in Durham. I introduced the students to knot theory and topology (including some topics that I only encountered in graduate school) and gave them their first taste of mathematics research.
  4. Since 2020, I have served as Director of Diversity and Inclusion for the Duke Mathematics Department. In that capacity, I assembled a committee of faculty, staff, and students to talk frankly about the climate of our department, particularly for members of underrepresented minorities, and to plan programming aimed at improving the culture. I have also been involved in various efforts aimed at recruiting minority candidates in admissions and hiring.
